awd_titl_txt: The Inclusive Connective Corridor: Social Networks and the ADVANCEment of Women STEM Faculty
awd_abstract_narration:
The Syracuse University ADVANCE project proposes to link the intellectual, cultural and economic development of women faculty in the STEM disciplines through a ?connective corridor? that is intended to create a sustained culture of equity for the campus.  To this end, the project has four initiatives that include: a networking initiative that links women faculty to each other and to potential mentors and other resources on campus; a corridor initiative that provides professional development and opportunities for partnerships with industry; a recruiting initiative that focuses on women of color and women with disabilities; and a practices initiative that supports leadership development for all faculty members.  

Intellectual Merit.  This project has impressive intellectual merit in that it combines well established social science research methods with social network analysis.  Additionally, the project uses novel approaches for the inclusion of male advocates and women from industry are highlighted in the proposal.  Other novel components related to this project include a 360o evaluation of the networking initiative, faculty of practice positions and fundraising to implement endowed professorships for women faculty.

Broader Impact.  The Syracuse University ADVANCE IT project will include women scientists from the academy and from industry.  As such, the breadth of the impact of this project extends far beyond the institution and includes atypical ADVANCE institutions as well.  Additionally, this project has a focus on an underserved population of women faculty in STEM disciplines, those of color and those with disabilities.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Syracuse University is a private research university with 1,165 full-time and 592 part-time faculty as of Fall 2016. In 2010, Syracuse University received funding from the National Science Foundation’s ADVANCE Institutional Transformation (IT) program to establish the project known as SU ADVANCE. The overarching mission of SU ADVANCE was to develop systematic approaches to transform the institution’s capacity for the recruitment, retention, and leadership development of women faculty in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines.

In the evaluation of project activities and concurrent research efforts, SU ADVANCE used network analysis to understand how the strategic use of professional and personal relationships could help achieve targeted outcomes. In this way, the work of SU ADVANCE has applicability to similar institutions seeking to support a more diverse STEM workforce, demonstrating its intended intellectual merit.

Initiatives built on results from social science research regarding professional networks and associated individual and organizational benefits. Such research suggests, for example, that faculty contribute to improved recruitment outcomes by connecting finalists to the broader SU community, including networking that would benefit dual career couples.

In 2010, among faculty who were tenured or on the tenure track (n=240), women represented 20.7% (n=49); data that are in line with national trends. In the fall of 2016, among tenured or tenure track faculty, women accounted for 27.2%. In Electrical Engineering and Computer Science disciplines, the proportion of women faculty increased from 6.4% to 21.9%, exceeding national trends. Recruiting efforts for tenure-track assistant professor positions resulted in a net change from 13 in 2010 to 25 in fall 2017, representing a 92.3% increase in the number of junior faculty women. By fall 2017, all full-time STEM women faculty numbered 101, an increase in number of 60.3% over the initial grant year (n=63).

A demonstrated contributing factor was the connections made between finalists and members of the SU community outside the hiring department. Analysis of recruitment data indicate that there is a statistically significant association (p<.05) between candidate meetings with representatives from the community and/or with a dual career coordinator and the acceptance of an employment offer made to a female candidate.

Research relying on network analysis also suggests that faculty who are well connected to a variety of peers in higher education and elsewhere build the skills and knowledge needed for promotion and long-term career success. SU ADVANCE offered external mentoring mini-grants, enabled women STEM faculty to work with career coaches, produced a mentoring toolkit (available at http://suadvance.syr.edu under Mentoring Resources) and provided an array of workshops.

These efforts resulted in an increase in the number of women at full professor and the number of women in leadership positions. In 2010, women represented 14.3% of all full professors in STEM. In 2016, women represented 21% of all full professors. This represents an increase in total number from 19 to 29, or 52.6%. This change occurred with no net decrease in the number of women associate professors, for which there was a positive change of 35.3% in number from 2010 to 2016 (from n=17 to n=23). Further, four STEM women currently hold deanships; two (of six) associate deans, three (of eleven) department chairs, and eighteen (of 44) program directors not otherwise serving in leadership positions are women. Importantly, four additional STEM women now hold named or distinguished professorships. Results observed from the use of novel network data collection instruments throughout the award demonstrate that those women who bridge departmental boundaries are located centrally in the overall network and well-positioned to achieve success.

Finally, network research suggested that relationships among faculty would be an effective means to share information and perspectives that ultimately contribute to better work environments. In addition to sharing information about the negative impact of implicit bias on overall equity, male and female faculty alike engaged in grassroots efforts to work with campus administration to build support for the creation of a dual career program (now housed in the Office of Human Resources) and advocated for specific changes in policy and procedure that address the needs of parents in the academic workplace.

Throughout the period of the award, both STEM faculty perceived the SU ADVANCE program as a vital resource aiding their individual and their departments’ ability to successfully recruit talented female faculty members and support their professional growth. In addition, members of the SU ADVANCE team shared information about the impact of the initiative and research findings through venues including the annual ADVANCE/GSE program meeting, the WEPAN Change Leaders’ Forum, the International Gender Summit, and meetings of the International Geosynthetics Society and the International Network of Social Network Analysts, the American Society of Civil Engineers’ GEO-CONGRESS, and the College and University Work Family Association Conference.


Last Modified: 12/29/2017
Modified by: Karen L Alston
